latest news.eng_title: Google appoints former Character.AI founder as co-lead of its AI models
latest news.summary: Google has appointed Noam Shazeer, the former head of Character.AI and a long-time Google researcher, as a co-lead of its AI models project, Gemini. Shazeer will join Jeff Dean and Oriol Vinyals in leading the project, which is being developed by DeepMind, Google's AI division. Shazeer rejoined Google after the company paid billions to bring him and other employees into DeepMind and strike a licensing agreement with Character.AI. Shazeer stated, 'We are thrilled to join the best team on earth building the most valuable technology on earth.' This move comes at a time when Big Tech companies are facing regulatory scrutiny, with Google recently being ruled to have violated antitrust law and spent billions to create an illegal monopoly.
latest news.title: Google appoints former Character.AI founder as co-lead of its AI models

latest news.eng_title: John Cena Opens Up on Brock Lesnar Amid WWE Hiatus Following Vince McMahon Sex-Trafficking Allegations
latest news.summary: John Cena praised Brock Lesnar's athleticism and in-ring prowess, saying, 'Brock is one of the most gifted, hardest-working, perseverant, stubborn sons of b*tches I've ever met.' Cena believes Lesnar could do anything he puts his mind to, citing his physical abilities and talent. Despite Lesnar's prolonged absence from WWE amid allegations of involvement in Vince McMahon's sex-trafficking lawsuit, Cena remains a fan of the Beast Incarnate. Lesnar's recent appearances have been limited, but he was seen taking photos with fans in a new look. Cena's last WWE appearance was at SummerSlam 2023, while Lesnar's return to action is uncertain due to the ongoing lawsuit. According to reports, Lesnar was set to return at Royal Rumble 2024, but his return is now dependent on the WWE's legal team.
latest news.title: John Cena Opens Up on Brock Lesnar Amid WWE Hiatus Following Vince McMahon Sex-Trafficking Allegations

latest news.eng_title: Google Appoints Noam Shazeer as Technical Lead of AI Models
latest news.summary: Google has appointed Noam Shazeer, the former co-founder of Character.AI, as the technical lead of its AI models, Gemini. Shazeer will join Jeff Dean and Oriol Vinyals as co-directors of the project. Shazeer, who recently joined Google after founding Character.AI in 2021, will be responsible for the technical direction of Gemini, a line of AI models developed by DeepMind, Google's AI division. The models are integrated into products such as Search and Pixel smartphones. Shazeer said, 'We are thrilled to join the best team in the world that builds the most precious technology in the world.' Google acquired Character.AI's technology and licensed it from the startup, which raised $193 million and was valued at $1 billion last year. The move comes as large tech companies face regulatory scrutiny, with Amazon and Microsoft also making similar moves to acquire top AI talent.
latest news.title: Google nomme l'ancien fondateur de Character.AI à la tête de ses modèles d'IA

latest news.eng_title: Atalanta's Ademola Lookman Returns to Training, Market Remains Open
latest news.summary: Ademola Lookman, a key player for Atalanta, has returned to training after being absent for several days. According to Gian Piero Gasperini, the team's coach, Lookman will be reintegrated into the team and should return to playing in the next few matches. However, the situation is not yet resolved, as there are still rumors of interest from Arsenal, and a concrete offer from Paris Saint-Germain has not been received. As a result, the market for Lookman remains open, and the situation will be closely monitored. As Gasperini said, 'L'idea è quella di farlo tornare a giocare già dai prossimi impegni' (the idea is to have him return to playing in the next few matches).
latest news.title: Atalanta, Lookman torna ad allenarsi: l'idea di Gasperini per lui e le voci sulla Premier

latest news.eng_title: Schwartzman and Sierra Advance in US Open
latest news.summary: Diego Schwartzman and Solana Sierra were the only Argentine players to advance in the US Open, defeating their opponents in the second round. Schwartzman, the eighth highest ranked player in the ATP in October 2020, defeated Thiago Tirante 7-5 and 4-6. He will face Vilius Gaubas in the next round, seeking a spot in the 64th round of the tournament. This could be his last Grand Slam appearance, as he announced his retirement in 2025. Sierra, ranked 159th, also advanced to the third round, defeating Ella Seidel 3-6, 7-5, and 6-2. She overcame a difficult first set and broke her opponent six times, sending Seidel, ranked 237th, home.
latest news.title: Schwartzman y Sierra avanzaron en el Grand Slam

latest news.eng_title: Remedy May Be Google's Biggest Hurdle Yet In Antitrust Case
latest news.summary: A recent U.S. District Court decision has held Google liable for monopolization of the general search market and the search text advertising market. This ruling may pose a significant challenge for Google in its antitrust case. According to the court, Google's dominance in these markets has led to a lack of competition, which can negatively impact consumers. The full implications of this decision are still to be determined, but it is clear that Google will face significant hurdles in its defense against the antitrust charges. As one might expect, Google's remedy may be its biggest hurdle yet in this case.
latest news.title: Remedy May Be Google's Biggest Hurdle Yet In Antitrust Case

latest news.eng_title: Google Says Wait Until The August Core Update Is Complete To Make Calls On Effects
latest news.summary: Google's John Mueller advises waiting until the August core update is fully rolled out before judging its effects. The update, which started on August 15th, is expected to take about a month to complete. However, a recent ranking bug has made it difficult to determine whether changes in ranking are due to the bug or the core update. Mueller suggests comparing the week or two prior to the core update to the week or two after it is completed to see the actual effects. He also emphasizes that most sites do not see big changes with core updates, and that it's not worth trying to separate out the effects from the ranking issue. As Mueller said, 'You'd really need to wait until the core update finishes rolling out to make any call about its effect.'
latest news.title: Google Says Wait Until The August Core Update Is Complete To Make Calls On Effects

latest news.eng_title: Brock Lesnar to return and challenge 37-year-old star to a big match at WWE Crown Jewel? Exploring the possibility
latest news.summary: Brock Lesnar, a WWE superstar, has been absent from the WWE for a year and his return is uncertain. However, Triple H has hinted at a comeback. If Lesnar returns, he is likely to challenge for a major title, possibly the World Heavyweight Championship. A match against Gunther at WWE Crown Jewel could be a good option, as Lesnar is a fan favorite in Saudi Arabia and the match would likely main event the show. Gunther has expressed his desire to face Lesnar, saying 'We'll see if there's a chance for it to happen again. I'm more than up for it. How the situation is exactly right now,' according to 411 Mania. Lesnar's return could also depend on Gunther's performance at Bash in Berlin, where he will face Randy Orton.
latest news.title: Brock Lesnar to return and challenge 37-year-old star to a big match at WWE Crown Jewel? Exploring the possibility

latest news.eng_title: I worked at Google for almost a decade. Its problem is bureaucracy — not hybrid working.
latest news.summary: Jordan Thibodeau, a former Google HR manager, disagrees with Eric Schmidt's comments that Google is falling behind due to remote working. Thibodeau, who worked at Google for nearly a decade, believes that bureaucracy is the real issue. He said that Google had the technology to support remote work, but chose not to act on it. Thibodeau also criticized Schmidt's comments as 'out of touch' and 'hurting a lot of people who don't have a voice inside Google.' He noted that Nvidia, a competitor, has a more flexible work-from-home policy and is still producing well. Thibodeau also spoke about the return-to-office (RTO) push at Google, which he believes is causing 'tremendous fear and anxiety' among employees. He said that many employees were under the impression that they could work from home permanently, but were instead forced to return to the office. Thibodeau left Google in 2020 to join Slack's M&A HR team, where he was offered a full-time work-from-home job. He believes that Schmidt's comments are 'tone-deaf and unproductive' and are causing unnecessary stress for Google employees.
latest news.title: I worked at Google for almost a decade. Its problem is bureaucracy — not hybrid working.

latest news.eng_title: Elon Musk Sues OpenAI Over Alleged Betrayal and Fraud
latest news.summary: Elon Musk has refiled a lawsuit against OpenAI, accusing its co-founders, Sam Altman and Greg Brockman, of betraying the company's founding mission. Musk claims that Altman 'manipulated and deceived' him, and that OpenAI's change from a non-profit to a for-profit organization was a 'long-term scam'. Musk originally invested in OpenAI in 2015 under the understanding that it would be a non-profit organization, but Altman allegedly assured him that the structure would guarantee neutrality and a focus on safety and openness for the benefit of humanity. However, OpenAI was recently valued at $100 billion and its leaders were 'unjustly enriched', according to the lawsuit. Musk claims that this change was a 'Shakespearean betrayal' and that Altman's actions were 'a classic story of altruism versus avarice'.
latest news.title: Elon Musk vs. Sam Altman: Magnate demanda a OpenAI por fraude y señala que lo "engañaron"

news knowledge.eng_title: OpenAI Experiences Another Round of High-Profile Departures
news knowledge.summary: Two key managers at OpenAI have resigned, while the president, Greg Brockman, will take a one-year leave of absence. The departures follow a series of similar moves, including the exits of Jan Leike, Ilya Sutskever, and Sam Altman. John Schulman, one of the founders, has joined rival Anthropic, stating, 'I have decided to pursue this goal in Anthropic, where I believe I can acquire new perspectives and conduct research with people deeply engaged in the topics that interest me most.' Greg Brockman, the other founder, has taken a leave of absence, citing a desire to take a break. Peter Deng, the head of consumer solutions, has also left the company, which he joined just a year ago. This latest wave of departures raises questions about OpenAI's stability and future prospects.
news knowledge.title: Lasciano altri due manager. Perché OpenAi sta perdendo pezzi?

news knowledge.eng_title: OpenAI Leaders Leave Amid Internal Tensions
news knowledge.summary: Three of OpenAI's leaders have left the company, adding to the internal tensions. Greg Brockman, one of the 11 co-founders, has taken a sabbatical until the end of the year, stating 'This is the first time I've relaxed since founding OpenAI 9 years ago. The mission is far from complete; we still need to create a safe AGI.' John Schulman, another co-founder, has joined Anthropic, a rival company, to pursue his goal of 'alignment' (fine-tuning models after initial training). Peter Deng, a product manager, left the company earlier, but the reason is unknown. This comes after Ilya Sutskever, another co-founder, left in May, citing disagreements with the company, and later joined Anthropic. Only three of the original 11 co-founders remain: Sam Altman, Brockman, and Wojciech Zaremba. The company has been in turmoil since Sam Altman's surprise return as CEO in November 2023, and these departures suggest a major internal crisis.
news knowledge.title: Desbandada en OpenAI: tres de sus líderes abandonan una compañía sacudida por las tensiones internas

news knowledge.eng_title: OpenAI Co-Founder Greg Brockman Takes Leave of Absence, Researcher John Schulman Joins Rival Anthropic
news knowledge.summary: Greg Brockman, co-founder and president of OpenAI, will take a leave of absence until the end of the year. Meanwhile, researcher John Schulman is leaving the company to join rival AI startup Anthropic. Both Brockman and Schulman are co-founders of OpenAI, and their departures mark a change in the company after significant management turnover this year. Brockman, known as 'GDB' within the company, was a key ally of CEO Sam Altman when he was briefly removed from his position last year. Brockman requested to leave the company in protest after Altman was fired. In a post on X, he wrote, 'I'm taking a year-long sabbatical until the end of the year. First time to relax since founding OpenAI, 9 years ago. The mission is far from over; we still have a safe AGI to build.' Schulman, who was a researcher at the company focused on training AI models, said in a post on X that he will focus on Anthropic's security, but that concerns about this issue did not motivate his decision to leave. 'To be clear, I'm not leaving due to lack of support for alignment research at OpenAI,' he said, referring to the alignment of AI with human interests. 'On the contrary, the company's leaders have committed to investing heavily in this area.' OpenAI stated that the team is 'grateful' for Schulman's work, including his alignment research. 'His passion and hard work have established a solid foundation that will inspire and support future innovations at OpenAI and in the broader field,' a spokesperson said. Schulman was hailed as the architect of ChatGPT, the popular chatbot of OpenAI. However, he said he receives 'too much credit' for the tool and cited the work of the entire team. In a post on X, Altman thanked Schulman for his work at the company and called him a 'brilliant researcher' and 'deep thinker'.
news knowledge.title: OpenAI perde arquiteto do ChatGPT e presidente tira sabático

news knowledge.eng_title: OpenAI Co-Founder Greg Brockman Takes Sabbatical Amid Leadership Changes
news knowledge.summary: Greg Brockman, co-founder and president of OpenAI, has announced his leave of absence to take a sabbatical. This comes after John Schulman, another co-founder and key leader, left the company to join rival Anthropic. Peter Deng, the product leader who joined the company last year, has also left OpenAI, according to The Information. Brockman, who played a crucial role in the company's recent changes, will be taking a break from the intense AI sector. He helped transform the discoveries of researchers into large-scale AI models and products like ChatGPT. Brockman said he plans to return after his extended vacation, but announced on X that he will be absent until the end of the year. Schulman led the post-training process, refining large language models that power ChatGPT and other products. He also took over a team focused on preventing AI from causing social harm. Other changes at OpenAI include the reassignment of security leader Aleksander Madry and the departure of co-founder Ilya Sutskever, who left to form a rival startup. Co-founder Andrej Karpathy also left in February to launch an educational startup. OpenAI has recently hired its first CFO and a new product director, which may have impacted Deng's role. The company is in the midst of transforming from a non-profit to a highly profitable corporation, and is currently training its next main model. They have also launched a search mechanism and are working on an AI agent that can automate computer tasks for clients.
news knowledge.title: Presidente da OpenAI pede licença para viver período sabático

news knowledge.eng_title: Two more OpenAI leaders are leaving the company
news knowledge.summary: Two key OpenAI personnel are leaving the company, while another is taking a months-long leave of absence. OpenAI president Greg Brockman is taking a sabbatical through the end of the year, while co-founder John Schulman is joining rival Anthropic. VP for consumer product Peter Deng is also leaving, citing a desire to return to hands-on technical work and focus on AI alignment. Brockman said in a post on X/Twitter that this is his 'first time to relax' since the founding of OpenAI nine years ago, and that he's coming back after his vacation. Schulman clarified that he's not leaving due to a lack of support for alignment research, and that the company's executives have been 'very committed to investing in this area.' These departures follow several major previous changes in OpenAI's leadership, including the departure of co-founder and Chief Scientist Ilya Sutskever in May.
news knowledge.title: Two more OpenAI leaders are leaving the company

news knowledge.eng_title: OpenAI Leadership in Flux: Brockman and Two Executives Depart
news knowledge.summary: OpenAI's President Greg Brockman and two other executives have left the company, according to a report by The Information. Brockman, one of the co-founders, will be taking a leave of absence for an extended period, while John Schulman, another co-founder, has joined competitor Anthiopic. Peter Deng, the product lead, has also left the company after only joining in 2023. Schulman confirmed his departure on his X account, where CEO Sam Altman thanked him for his services. Brockman and Deng could not be reached for comment. The departures are not related to each other, but reflect the ongoing changes at OpenAI following the sudden firing and re-hiring of Altman in November 2023. This move sparked controversy over OpenAI's corporate structure. The report comes weeks after Microsoft and Apple withdrew their applications for a seat on OpenAI's board, amid a growing antitrust review of the company and its partners. Additionally, Elon Musk has re-filed a lawsuit against OpenAI and Altman, alleging that the company prioritizes profits over public welfare.
news knowledge.title: OpenAI: Führungskräfte werfen hin – verlieren die Gründer den Glauben an das Projekt?

news knowledge.eng_title: OpenAI president, two other leaders leave- The Information By Investing.com
news knowledge.summary: OpenAI President Greg Brockman and two other leaders, including cofounder John Schulman and product leader Peter Deng, have left the company. According to The Information, Brockman will take an extended leave of absence, while Schulman has joined rival Anthiopic. Deng's departure comes after joining OpenAI in 2023. The exits are reportedly unrelated, but reflect continued upheaval at the company following the abrupt firing and rehiring of CEO Sam Altman in November 2023. As The Information noted, the move has sparked controversy over OpenAI's operational structure, amid growing antitrust scrutiny and a lawsuit filed by Tesla CEO Elon Musk.
news knowledge.title: OpenAI president, two other leaders leave- The Information By Investing.com

news knowledge.eng_title: OpenAI Executives Depart Amid Ongoing Turmoil
news knowledge.summary: Greg Brockman, the president of OpenAI, and two other executives have left the artificial intelligence startup, according to a report by The Information. Brockman, one of the co-founders of the company, will be taking a prolonged leave of absence, The Information reported, citing a source familiar with the matter. John Schulman, another co-founder, has joined the rival company Anthiopic, while the product lead Peter Deng has left the company after joining in 2023. Schulman confirmed his departure on his X account, where CEO Sam Altman thanked him for his service. Brockman and Deng could not be immediately reached for comment. The Information stated that the three departures were not related, but reflected the ongoing turmoil within the AI startup after Altman's brutal firing and rehiring in November 2023. This decision had sparked controversy over OpenAI's operational structure. The report comes weeks after reports showed that Microsoft Corporation and Apple Inc had withdrawn their offers for seats on OpenAI's board of directors, in the context of growing antitrust scrutiny of the company and its partners.
news knowledge.title: Le président d'OpenAI et deux autres dirigeants claquent la porte

news knowledge.eng_title: OpenAI president, two other leaders leave- The Information
news knowledge.summary: OpenAI President Greg Brockman and two other leaders, including cofounder John Schulman, have left the company. Brockman will take an extended leave of absence, while Schulman has joined rival Anthiopic. Product leader Peter Deng has also left after joining in 2023. According to The Information, the exits are unrelated but reflect continued upheaval at OpenAI after the firing and rehiring of CEO Sam Altman in November 2023. The move has sparked controversy over OpenAI's operational structure. As reported by The Information, Microsoft and Apple had dropped their bids for board seats in the AI major amid growing antitrust scrutiny. 'I want to thank John Schulman for his service,' Altman said on X, confirming Schulman's exit.
news knowledge.title: OpenAI president, two other leaders leave- The Information

news knowledge.eng_title: One of OpenAI's co-founders departs; company president is taking an extended leave
news knowledge.summary: OpenAI co-founder John Schulman is leaving the company to join rival Anthropic, citing a desire to focus on AI alignment and return to hands-on technical work. Schulman stated, 'This choice stems from my desire to deepen my focus on AI alignment, and to start a new chapter of my career where I can return to hands-on technical work.' OpenAI CEO Sam Altman thanked Schulman for his efforts, saying, 'You are a brilliant researcher, a deep thinker about product and society, and mostly, you are a great friend to all of us.' Meanwhile, OpenAI president Greg Brockman is taking an extended leave of absence, and product manager Peter Deng is reportedly leaving the company completely. The reasons for Brockman's and Deng's departures are unclear.
news knowledge.title: One of OpenAI's co-founders departs; company president is taking an extended leave
